entry.title: Re: Cannot add Search Help to Custom Field - "No suitable...
entry.content:
Hello @nevenjakopcic ,

Thank you for sharing the screenshot.

What is causing the error, and what is the solution?

The error No suitable value help key field exists occurs when the selected value-help CDS does not expose a suitable key for binding. SAP‚Äôs KBA confirms this issue and indicates it relates to the key/length/type compatibility of the value-help view. SAP Support Portal-3603837 - "No suitable value help key field exists" when trying to change the Value Help View of a Custom Field

The value-help CDS should contain exactly one element marked as Value Help Key Field, and this element must be of type Text (Edm.String).

In your evaluation of YY1_PERSONNEL_Search, no element has been assigned as the key, and since the Personnel Number seems to be numeric, it will not be usable as a value help key.

Also check KBA 3207015 - Adding a Value Help with the Custom CDS Views App - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

With best regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Non SAP System Integration with SAP GTS for complianc...
entry.content:
Dharmesh,

Calling the GTS API from the external application is the easiest way to process the master/transaction data and it would fetch the results just like GTS would do when plugged into ECC/S4H. But with direct call from the non-SAP system there is some extra work you will need to do to decode the messages and transmit back to the calling application in a consumable way that can be easily interpreted for an actionable response.

Alternatively, piggy back on the RFC's from ECC/S4H by calling it from the external application and let the native code in ECC/S4H do the decoding for you to be sent to the external application in a consumable way.

We used /SAPSLL/API_6800_SYNCH_MASS - API for Custom document creation/change for calling from Salesforce application via S4H to perform all the compliance screening. Our Master data system of record for GTS as well as Salesforce was S4H. Hence, there was no replication required for Master data from Salesforce as the data was timely transmitted to GTS from S4H.

Hope this helps.

Best,

Prashant

entry.title: TM Scheduling in Stock Transport Order
entry.content:
Dear friends of TM,

With SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS1 we published our first version of the TM based sales order scheduling (see respective blog post).

In this context we thankfully received a lot of feedback, and by far the most asked question has been whether we plan also to offer a TM based scheduling for stock transport orders. That‚Äôs why we published another blog post describing how this can be achieved with a modification-free customer own implementation.

Now, with SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0 we can publish also a TM based scheduling for stock transport orders in standard, which will be described in the following.

Scenario

Like the TM based sales order scheduling, we‚Äôre integrated with Business Process Scheduling (BPS) in the following way:

  1. The requested delivery date from the schedule line of the stock transport order is the input for the BPS, where the calculation of the relevant dates is managed.
  2. Based on the requested delivery date, Transportation Management (TM) can calculate durations for loading, transport and unloading, ending up in a requested picking date by backward scheduling. From that, BPS calculates a requested material availability date as input for Available-to-Promise (ATP).
  3. ATP confirms a material availability date of the product from which BPS calculates the respective confirmed picking date.
  4. If this confirmed picking date differs from the requested picking date, TM calculates the confirmed delivery date with forward scheduling. Otherwise, the requested delivery date becomes the confirmed delivery date.

Key features

In its first version, the TM based scheduling of stock transport orders will not have equivalent functionality as the TM based sales order scheduling. Though, there are many similarities and it‚Äôs surely already usable very well.

Some of the key features are:

  • TM scheduling calculates durations for transport-relevant activities such as loading, transport and unloading during the creation of a stock transport order.
  • The scheduling in TM considers the transportation network as maintained in master data, e.g. default routes and straight line distances and durations. Also, Network Path Determination can be used.
  • The user can configure the sequence of routing methods how the scheduling in TM should be executed by the transportation duration determination profile at the TM control key.
  • Incoterm locations of the stock transport order are considered as the calculated delivery date relates to the arrival of the cargo at the incoterm location.
  • Delivery-based scenarios are supported where the freight units are only created during delivery integration. Scenarios without order or delivery integration are also supported.
  • Only scenarios with TM embedded in S/4HANA are supported, no scenarios with TM standalone.
  • TM scheduling is enabled on the level of document type / purchasing organization / purchasing group.

Example

Let‚Äôs explain this in detail with an example.

Prerequisite is the correct setup of the BPS:

So, you need to first create a schema or use an existing one. And afterwards this schema must be assigned in the ‚ÄòActivate BPS for Stock Transport Documents path.

Regarding the schema, see this exemplary one called ‚ÄòSTOCK_TRANSP_DAYS_ADV_ATTRIB‚Äô:

  • The loading duration is from the start of loading until the goods issue.
  • The transport duration is from goods issue until the delivery at the destination location (which can also be an incoterm location).
  • The unloading duration is from the delivery until the goods receipt.

Afterwards TM needs to be set up:

In Logistics Integration customizing, a TM control key needs to be assigned. This TM control key needs a TRS profile containing e.g. the planning profile with the loading / unloading durations and the routing method(s). Besides, the TM control key can be set up with or without TM integration depending on whether you just want to use the TM scheduling or also create freight units for the transport demands and use the further TM capabilities.

 If you now capture your stock transport order, the tab ‚Äòdelivery schedule‚Äô on item level will be filled with the information of the TM scheduling:

Best regards,

Michael

entry.title: Error 500 in CAP entitySet READ
entry.content:
Hi everyone, I'm new to CAP development. I ran into this problem when building a simple demo in the trial environment.

I have successfully deployed my CAP application to BTP and can access the service metadata.

https://xxxtrial-dev-moe-cap-backend-srv.cfapps.us10-001.hana.ondemand.com/odata/v4/My_SRV/$metadata

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

But when I access the entitySet, I get the following error:

https://xxxtrial-dev-moe-cap-backend-srv.cfapps.us10-001.hana.ondemand.com/odata/v4/My_SRV/MoeSet

 

 

 

I generated the CAP framework using the following command: 

mvn -B archetype:generate -DarchetypeArtifactId=cds-services-archetype -DarchetypeGroupId=com.sap.cds -DarchetypeVersion=RELEASE -DgroupId=com.moe.company -DartifactId=moe-cap-backend -Dpackage=com.moe.company.moecapbackend

 

Then I created capservice.cds under the srv directory with the following content:

service My_SRV {
    @requires: 'any'
    entity MoeSet as projection on TestSet;
}

entity TestSet {
    key testKey : String(64);
    inputData : String(100);
    memo: String(100);
    outputData: String(100);
}

And I also created a MyServiceHandler.java file under the main directory with the following content:

package com.moe.company.mycapbackend;

import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Map;
import com.sap.cds.services.cds.CdsReadEventContext;
import com.sap.cds.services.cds.CqnService;
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.EventHandler;
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.annotations.On;
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.annotations.ServiceName;
import com.sap.cds.services.request.UserInfo;
import cds.gen.my_srv.MoeSet;


@ServiceName("My_SRV")
public class MyServiceHandler implements EventHandler {

  @On(event = CqnService.EVENT_READ, entity = "My_SRV.MoeSet")
  public void beforeReadProducts(CdsReadEventContext context) {
    UserInfo userInfo = context.getUserInfo();

    MoeSet datamodel = com.sap.cds.Struct.create(MoeSet.class);
    datamodel.put(MoeSet.MEMO, userInfo.getName());

    Map<Object, Map<String, Object>> result = new HashMap<>();
    String key ="test1";
    result.put(key, datamodel);

    context.setResult(result.values());

  }
}

Since this is just a simple practice, I didn't add authentication. Here's my mta.yaml file:

_schema-version: 3.3.0
ID: moe-cap-backend
version: 1.0.0-SNAPSHOT
description: "A simple CAP project."
parameters:
  enable-parallel-deployments: true
modules:
  - name: moe-cap-backend-srv
    type: java
    path: srv
    parameters:
      instances: 1
      buildpack: sap_java_buildpack_jakarta
    properties:
      SPRING_PROFILES_ACTIVE: cloud,sandbox
      JBP_CONFIG_COMPONENTS: "jres: ['com.sap.xs.java.buildpack.jre.SAPMachineJRE']"
      JBP_CONFIG_SAP_MACHINE_JRE: '{ version: 17.+ }'
    build-parameters:
      builder: custom
      commands:
        - mvn clean package -DskipTests=true --batch-mode
      build-result: target/*-exec.jar
    provides:
      - name: srv-api # required by consumers of CAP services (e.g. approuter)
        properties:
          srv-url: ${default-url}

 

Are there any steps I might have missed?

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud | Cost Estimation by Batch
entry.content:
Hello @hanna_tran,

Thank you for your follow-up and questions,

You asked, ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt create a standard cost per valuation type because CK11N lost the field.‚Äù
CK11N no longer requires a valuation type input. In S/4HANA Cloud, costs are generated and released using Fiori costing apps instead of CK11N. The cost estimates can now be created based on valuation types for split-valuated materials; this feature has been transferred to Fiori for both with and without quantity-structure processes. You then release the price per valuation type in Manage Material Valuations.  SAP Help-Material Cost Estimate Without Quantity Structure

And your second question: ‚ÄúCan we control costs from production into valuation types and through to GI?‚Äù
Yes, with the right setup:

Use Split Valuation (Single Batch Valuation) for SFG and FG, ensuring each batch has its own valuation type. This allows inventory values and COGS to vary by batch. SAP Help-Production Accounting Split Valuation

Run, mark, or release a cost estimate for each valuation type for the SFG and FG. The standard price is set at the valuation-type level, so the planned costs of SFG batches are included in the FG valuation type. At goods issue, COGS posts using the FG batch valuation type. SAP Help-Material Cost Estimate Without Quantity Structure

If you also want period-end ‚Äúactuals‚Äù by batch, activate Actual Costing (scope item 33Q) so the Material Ledger revalues inventory and consumption per valuation type at month-end. Actual Costing (33Q)

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: SAP B1 HANA - USER QUERIES How to change parameter name in user queries
entry.content:
The following query is created  to get the back dated entries in cross financial year.

SELECT J0."TransId", J0."CreateDate"
, NJ."SeriesName" AS "JvSeries", J0."Number" AS "JvNum", J0."RefDate"
, OL."U_tblDesc" AS "DocType", J0."CreatedBy" AS "DocEntry", ND."SeriesName" AS "DocSeries", J0."BaseRef" AS "DocNum"
, J0."LocTotal", J0."Memo", J0."DataSource", OUSR."U_NAME" AS "U_NAME",
DAYS_BETWEEN(J0."RefDate", J0."CreateDate") AS "Date Diff"
FROM OJDT J0
INNER JOIN NNM1 NJ ON J0."Series" = NJ."Series"
INNER JOIN "SAP_SUPPORT"."tblObjList" OL on J0."TransType" = OL."U_tblObjType"
INNER JOIN NNM1 ND ON J0."DocSeries" = ND."Series"
INNER JOIN OUSR ON J0."UserSign" = OUSR."USERID"
WHERE
DAYS_BETWEEN(J0."RefDate", J0."CreateDate") > 30
AND YEAR(ADD_MONTHS(J0."CreateDate", -3)) <> YEAR(ADD_MONTHS(J0."RefDate", -3))
AND YEAR(ADD_MONTHS(J0."CreateDate", -3)) = 2025
ORDER BY 2 DESC

now i want to select "No of Days" parameter to select the entries which are backdated then no of days ie in Queries 30 and "Financial Year" Like '2025'. 

How can i set the parameter and Parameter Name in this Query ?

i used [%0] and [%1] in place of 30, and 2025,

Parameter screen shows 

Instead of Numeric value it ask the date value ?

Please give the solutions  to take numeric value for this?

Regards

 

Narendra Dashpute 

sapsupport@dynamicprestress.co.in

9420690395

The fact that an end-user might mistake a CSV for an XLSX file just because Excel opens when double-clicking a CSV file (a Windows behaviour) is unfortunate but excusable. That a technical person also confuses them, to the point of renaming it, not as much: Excel is simply telling you that the extension (XLSX) does not match the file internal structure (CSV).

  • install abap2xlsx and enjoy full control over the generation

entry.title: Re: F111 No postings orders generated
entry.content:
The error you're encountering‚ÄîFZ330 and FZ311‚Äîtypically stems from incomplete or mismatched configuration of payment methods, currencies, or mandates in SAP Public Cloud. Even if Payment Method E is allowed for USD in CBC, other dependencies may be missing.

Please check in the below areas

Ensure Payment Method E is correctly defined for the company code, country, and currency (USD). In FBZP ‚Üí Payment Methods in Company Code, verify Currency field includes USD,
Minimum/Maximum Amounts are not restricting the payment. Bank selection is enabled and correctly linked.

In BP transaction, check Payment Method E is assigned under Payment Transactions. Bank details are complete and valid. Currency USD is allowed for the vendor.

Confirm that Payment Method E is enabled for USD, mapped to a valid House Bank and Bank Account and not restricted by any payment block or mandate requirement.

In FBZP ‚Üí Bank Determination, verify Ranking order includes a bank that supports USD and Payment Method E. Bank Accounts are correctly assigned and active.

Finally, activate Additional Log in F110 parameters like Check ‚ÄúPayment Method Selection‚Äù and ‚ÄúMaster Data‚Äù options. This will show why a payment method was rejected.

entry.title: Trigger Equipment Replication (Event Mesh) from S/4HANA Public Cloud to Service Cloud V2
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

I set up the integration of Equipments based on the SAP Standard guide to replicate Equipments from S/4HANA Public Cloud to Service Cloud V2. The integration is done via SAP Event Mesh, configured on BTP.

The replication works fine when equipments are created or changed in S4, but I would need to trigger an initial load of all (incl. old) equipments. The guide does not provide any information how this can be done, and since there is no replication model for this event based integration, I cannot trigger it like the other master data interfaces.

Does anyone have a hint on how this can be achieved without having to change every single equipment in S4?

Thanks in advance!
BR,
Richard

entry.title: Intelligent Natural-Language Interaction in ABAP UIs ‚Äî Introducing the FPM GenAI Service
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

With the upcoming ABAP Platform 2025 and SAP S/4HANA 2025 Private Cloud Edition, the new FPM GenAI Service offers a new way to bring AI-powered interaction into classical FPM-based applications.
This service can be consumed via SAP BTP credits and is designed to seamlessly integrate large language models (LLMs) into ABAP-based UIs.

The Floorplan Manager (FPM) UI Framework provides an especially suitable foundation for this, thanks to its event-based control flow and stateful backend integration ‚Äî both essential for combining generative AI logic with transactional business processes.

What is the FPM GenAI Service?

The FPM GenAI Service enables developers to connect their FPM applications with LLMs in order to interpret natural-language user input and transform it into application-specific operations at runtime.

Instead of navigating through the user interface in a traditional way, users can simply express their intent in natural language ‚Äî for example:

‚ÄúPlease create a new business partner for SAP Deutschland SE & Co. KG‚Äù
‚ÄúShow all open invoices from last month‚Äù

The service interprets the user‚Äôs request and executes the corresponding FPM events in the backend.

Key benefits:

  • Users no longer need expert-level knowledge about the UI or data model.

  • Reduced number of manual UI steps ‚Äî one prompt replaces multiple operations.

  • Improved accessibility for occasional or business users.

Architecture Overview:

Architecture Overview of the FPM GenAI Service

Step-by-Step Integration Guide for Application Developers

The following steps outline how to enable AI-driven interaction in an existing FPM application.

1. Define AI Use Cases

Collect all possible actions your application can perform that make sense for AI interaction.
Examples:

  • ‚ÄúCreate a new business partner‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúDisplay all open sales orders for customer XYZ‚Äù

2. Define Parameters

Each operation may require parameters such as NAME, ADDRESS or SALES_ORDER_ID.
Collect them and describe how they relate to the operation.

3. Add Natural Language Descriptions

Provide concise, meaningful text descriptions for both operations and parameters.
Keep them short and precise ‚Äî the LLM will use these to interpret prompts accurately.
(English is recommended for maintainability.)

4. Integrate AI into the UI

At the current stage, you can integrate the AI trigger via a button in your FPM toolbar.
In the demo applications, this is done using a button with an AI icon (sap-icon://ai), which opens the FPM Prompt RUIBB (component FPM_AI_QUICK_PROMPT).
A deeper integration with SAP Joule in the Fiori Launchpad is planned for the future.

5. Register Your Operations

Once your operations, parameters, and descriptions are ready, register them in the FPM GenAI Manager.

DATA: ls_operations TYPE if_fpm_genai_manager=>ty_s_operation,
      lt_operations TYPE if_fpm_genai_manager=>ty_t_operation,
      ls_parameter  TYPE if_fpm_genai_manager=>ty_s_parameter.

ls_operations-event_id    = 'AI_CREATE_BP'.
ls_operations-description = 'create a new business partner (BP)'.
ls_parameter-name         = 'COMPANY_NAME'.
ls_parameter-description  = 'only the company name (without legal form)'.
APPEND ls_parameter TO ls_operations-parameters.
APPEND ls_operations TO lt_operations.

DATA(lo_fpm_genai_manager) = cl_fpm_factory=>get_instance( )->get_genai_manager( ).
lo_fpm_genai_manager->set_operations( lt_operations ).

It‚Äôs recommended to register only those operations that are relevant to the current screen ‚Äî this keeps prompts short and improves accuracy.

6. Execute the User Request

When the user submits a prompt, obtain the GenAI Manager API and call:

lo_fpm_genai_manager->execute_user_request( ).

7. Process the FPM Event

After receiving the LLM response, the FPM GenAI Manager creates and raises FPM events.
Handle these events in your implementation of IF_FPM_UI_BUILDING_BLOCK, typically in the method PROCESS_EVENT( ).

8. Handle Errors Gracefully

Use exception class CX_FPM_GENAI for error handling.
Possible cases include:

  • NO_USER_INPUT

  • USER_INPUT_ERROR

  • NO_OPERATIONS

  • GENAI_SDK_ERROR

Use the FPM Message Manager to communicate errors back to the user:

DATA(lo_msg_manager) = cl_fpm_factory=>get_instance( )->get_message_manager( ).
lo_msg_manager->report_error( cx_fpm_genai=>get_text( ) ).

That's everything for now üôÇ Now, let's check out the first

Example: EPM Demo Application (S_EPM_UX_BP)

The EPM demo application (S_EPM_UX_BP) has been enhanced to showcase the new GenAI capabilities.
The scenario demonstrates how the AI assistant can help with tasks such as creating business partners, listing products, and generating sales orders.

Step 1 ‚Äì Create a New Business Partner

From the result list toolbar, select the AI button (‚ÄúNew‚Äù) and enter one of the following prompts:

‚ÄúPlease add a new business partner in the role customer, name = SAP Deutschland SE & Co. KG, street = Hasso-Plattner-Ring 7, city = 69190 Walldorf.‚Äù
‚ÄúHi, we have a new customer. Copy the details from their imprint page.‚Äù

Each of these prompts triggers the creation of a new business partner in the ‚ÄúCustomer‚Äù role.
The AI framework interprets both structured and casual prompts and even derives parameter values (e.g., currency from country).

Step 2 ‚Äì Find Suitable Products

Next, the user can ask for product recommendations:

‚ÄúPlease compile a list of products that fit into the category laptops.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe customer wants laptops.‚Äù

The AI assistant understands synonyms (‚Äúlaptop‚Äù ‚Üî ‚Äúnotebook‚Äù) thanks to semantic enrichment in parameter definitions.

Step 3 ‚Äì Create a Sales Order

Finally, the user can create a sales order:

‚ÄúPlease create a new sales order with each of the listed products.‚Äù
‚ÄúCreate a new SO, 10 items each, except the cheapest one.‚Äù

The AI framework handles parameter logic and even comparative instructions (‚Äúexcept the cheapest one‚Äù).

Outlook and Further Resources

In upcoming releases, tighter integration with SAP Joule and Fiori Launchpad will further streamline the AI experience across the SAP ecosystem.

For more details, please refer to the SAP Help documentation.

You may also combine the new AI feature with the new FPM Camera and Audio functionalities.

Thanks to our developers ‚ù§Ô∏è and I hope you like it üôÇ

entry.title: What's new in SAP Cloud Application Programming Model ‚Äì September 2025
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

I‚Äôm happy to announce that the September release of SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) is available. It‚Äôs packed with many great new features! This blog post highlights some of the new features. It presents a range of exciting new capabilities, such as the new MCP servers or the integration with Application Frontend service. In addition, we collected some informative blog posts delving into various aspects of CAP and give you an overview on upcoming events.

Check out the details of what's new!

 

Enabling Agentic Development with MCP Servers

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is an open standard that bridges the gap between large language models (LLMs) and external resources such as services, tools, data, and workflows, so models can fetch context, take actions, and deliver more accurate results. MCP is already supported by clients such as Claude, Cline, Cursor, and VS Code.

Beginning of September, SAP introduced MCP servers for CAP, SAP Fiori elements, and SAPUI5. These MCP servers are designed specifically for building enterprise-grade SAP business applications taking into account proven best practices and providing recommendations tailored to SAP Business Technology Platform.

Welcome to cap-js/mcp-server

For further information, I highly recommend you to read this blog post: SAP Build introduces new MCP Servers to enable agentic development for Enterprise Applications.

 

Easily Integrate with Application Frontend Service

The Application Frontend service is a SaaS application on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), which serves as a single entry point for hosting, serving and operating frontend applications. It is part of SAP Build, SAP‚Äôs unified solution for application development and process automation. By consolidating all aspects of UI application management under one managed service, Application Frontend service simplifies the development experience and enhances custom application operations. For an introduction to Application Frontend service, please read this blog post.

With our latest CAP release it is now possible to easily integrate the Application Frontend service. All you have to do is use the command cds add app-frontend. This adds all the needed configuration to your project providing you access to Application Frontend‚Äôs cool features. No additional work for you to do!

Please note: The support for this service is currently limited to single-tenant applications.

 

Integration with SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh now Generally Available

SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh enables real-time, asynchronous communication. It works across hybrid, multi-cloud, and edge environments. The advanced event mesh integrates SAP and non-SAP systems into your event-driven architecture and allows you to form meshes of event brokers. You can publish and subscribe to business events from all kinds of SAP and non-SAP event sources. As a result, event-driven architecture and advanced event mesh keep systems and users up to date when critical changes occur. Advanced event mesh allows to manage, monitor, and visualize decentralized event streaming across your landscape.

In May, we released the beta version of our integration with advanced event mesh. After a successful test and evaluation phase, we are now happy to tell you that both open-source plugins (for Node.js and for Java) are now generally available (GA). The GA release comes with a notable addition: the support for cross-subaccount broker validation, allowing you to share advanced event mesh instances between multiple subaccounts.

Additional details can be found here.

 

Translated Error Messages in CAP Node.js

For a better user experience, error messages that appear on the UI should be translated into the same language as the rest of their application. Therefore, CAP Node.js delivers translations for annotation-based input validations out of the box in all CAP-supported languages. For a list of the messages that are currently translated, see the documentation.

Screenshot: Translation of error codes to German language

To learn more about error handling in Node.js, please read the following section in the documentation. For additional information about internationalization in Node.js, check out this section.

For those of you, who use CAP Java: translated error messages are also supported there. Please look at the documentation, to gain further insights.

 

Further Readings & Events

Avoiding Data Loss When Loading Initial Data with CSV Files in CAP

Using CSV files to load initial data or sample data is convenient but you must be careful when deploying data to SAP S/4HANA Cloud as you might risk losing data. In his blog post Avoiding Data Loss When Loading Initial Data with CSV Files in CAP, SAP Champion Mio Yasutake explains alternative approaches how to avoid data loss.

 

Providing Feedback on CAP Documentation

Your feedback is crucial for us to improve. Thus, we would like to ask you to share your feedback on our CAP documentation. There are many ways to provide us your feedback. In his blog post Multiple Ways to Give Feedback on CAP Documentation, my colleague Rene guides you through the different options.

 

SAP Cloud Application Programming Model Customer Roundtable

The next CAP Customer Roundtable is just around the corner. If you are interested in an overview of the recent features, demos, presentations and questions raised by the CAP community, mark your calendar for October 15th, 2025, 11 AM EST | 5 PM CE(S)T. Find further details (including the agenda and dial in data) in this blog post.

 

Devtoberfest 2025

Devtoberfest 2025 already started. In 2025, the event is taking place from September 29th until October 24th. But you can still consume the content. Devtoberfest is a virtual event giving SAP developers a great opportunity to get ready for SAP TechEd. It is packed with enablement sessions around topics in the area of CAP, ABAP, Tooling and Frontend, Integration, Data and AI, combined with a lot of fun. For further information, read the Devtoberfest 2025 Welcome! blog post and join the Devtoberfest group in SAP Community to take part in this great event!

 

SAP TechEd 2025

From November 4‚Äì6, 2025 SAP TechEd takes place providing you the opportunity to learn about the latest innovations and advancements in SAP technologies and to connect with the community. In 2025, SAP TechEd will be a hybrid event combining the best of both worlds: the in-person event in Berlin and the virtual event. Both events are taking place in parallel. Make sure to save the date and register now for Berlin or virtual!

The session catalogs for the in-person and the virtual event are now live, featuring a wide range of topics across various tracks, where you'll find many sessions on the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model.

 

For further information on new features, please have a look at the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model Release Notes. If you want to stay up-to-date with news, learning resources, and product and strategy updates for CAP: follow our tag in the SAP Community.

We look forward to seeing how you use these new capabilities to create innovative solutions and drive your projects forward. Stay tuned for more updates and happy coding! üòä

entry.title: The New Cloud Foundry Pipeline in SAP Continuous Integration and Delivery
entry.content:
• Version 3 of the Cloud Foundry Environment Pipeline is Here
  • Why the Cloud Foundry Environment Pipeline needed an Update
  • Changes in Version 3
  • Removal of On/Off Switches
  • API Redesign
  • In-repository Configuration Format
  • New Features
  • Build Descriptors
  • MTA Extension Descriptors
  • Getting There: The Migration

Version 3 of the Cloud Foundry Environment Pipeline is Here

At the end of September 2025, the version 3 of the Cloud Foundry Environment pipeline was released in the SAP Continuous Integration and Delivery service. This means, in a nutshell:

  • New Cloud Foundry Environment  jobs created with the UI will already have version 3.
  • Until January 15, 2026, version 2 jobs will function normally. It will still be possible to create them via the API.
  • Tooling is available to migrate from version 2 to 3.
  • On January 15, 2026, all remaining version 2 jobs will be migrated automatically.

This blog post describes our motivation for doing this change and highlights some key aspects. If you are more interested in using the new pipeline right away, check out the official documentation.

Why the Cloud Foundry Environment Pipeline needed an Update

The "Cloud Foundry Environment" pipeline is our most widely used pipeline. Hence, it was the focus of the development team to continuously provide improvements. The former version 2 of the pipeline was already quite dated and had acquired some historical baggage.  So in order to further improve it, a fresh start was required--in other words: We needed to do incompatible changes.

That being said, we do understand that our customer base has made a huge investment into the existing version by configuring thousands of jobs. To safeguard this investment, we build migration functionality to allow a seamless transition to the new version.

But before discussing this, let's look at the most important changes.

Changes in Version 3

Removal of On/Off Switches

Previously, lots of configuration elements could be switched on or off:

These switches are now gone. That makes the UI less cluttered and more intuitive: Instead of switching on an element before configuring it, you now just add the element using the "+" button:

If you no longer want a configuration element, you will have to delete it. If you want to preserve the data you have entered, create a safety copy of the entire job using the copy button in the job details view.

API Redesign

Not only did we work on the UI, but also on the API, i.e. the structure of the payload data clients have to send to create/update a job. We improved field names and got rid of some inconsistencies.

If you want to use the API directly to create jobs, you can find the complete specification of the payload as a JSON schema document which is available in our API as a resource. To access it, open the front page of the SAP Continuous Integration and Delivery UI. Now, in the browser's address bar, remove everything after the hostname and replace it with /v2. Hit enter, and you get to the front page of our API. From here, you can browse the complete API by following links. The path /v2.1/pipelineDefinitions/cf-env/3.0/schema will get you to the schema document for the Cloud Foundry Environment version 3 pipeline.

 

In-repository Configuration Format

Previously, there was a special format to be used when providing in-repository configuration for a job via a .pipeline/config.yaml file. This format has been removed. Instead, the same format as in the API payload is to be used. In particular, what we said above about the JSON schema applies here as well. The only difference is that, for convenience,  YAML can be used instead of JSON. Here is an example of a simple configuration for a job doing a build, deployment and test. To avoid ambiguity, the configuration file name in version 3 is .cid_service/config.yaml.

---
stages:
  build:
    buildTool: "mta"
    buildToolVersion: "MBTJ21N22"
    npmLint:
      failOnError: true
  malwareScan:
    scan: true
  acceptance:
    webdriverIoTests:
      npmScript: "wdi5"
      baseUrl: "https://www.test.com"
      credential: "test-cred"
    cfDeploy:
      credential: "test-cred"
      apiEndpoint: "https://www.test.com"
      org: "org"
      space: "space"
      strategy: "default"

 If you are familiar with the old format, you will realize, that this is much more simple and concise than what we had before.

New Features

Build Descriptors

Every project has a build descriptor file. Depending on the technology, it could be a mta.yaml, a package.json or a pom.xml. Instead of assuming this file is always located in the project root folder, you can now specify a path relative to the project root. For example: code/mta.yaml. This allows for a more flexible project structure.

MTA Extension Descriptors

In the MTA use case, so-called extension descriptors are used for providing configuration that is specific for a certain deployment. For example, you might want to configure more application instances in the release stage for your productive deployment than in the acceptance stage for your test deployment.

This feature is now fully supported by the service, i.e., you can specify a list of extension descriptor files to go with each deployment.

Getting There: The Migration

First the good news: If you have a version 2 job which is configure with the Job Editor, the migration is basically just a click. Just use the "Migrate" button in the job details view, and the service is taking care of the rest. Since the migration cannot be undone, consider creating a "safety copy" using the copy button.

You can also decide to do nothing for now, since on January 15, 2026, all remaining jobs will be migrated automatically.

It is a bit more complicated for jobs with in-repository configuration, because we cannot just push a commit in your repository migrating the configuration. Instead, if you use the migration button for the in-repository configured job, you will be asked to paste the content of your .pipeline/config.yml file. The result will be the expected content of the new .sap_cid/config.yml file. Create this file in your repository, commit everything and finish the migration flow in the UI. Note that for jobs with in-repository configuration, you need take active steps to complete the migration. Otherwise, they will stop working on January 15, 2026.

For more details on the migration, check out our official documentation.

entry.title: Re: Common configuration issues: Joule for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
entry.content:
In case you don't find anything in the SCC trace (assuming you did set the trace to highest possible details), then The WZ is not forwarding the requests to your backend. Some of configuration is not done correctly.

When setting up Joule I do follow the official guide, here is a link to the live and constantly updated PDF:

Official "How To Joule" PDF

Roles must be loaded to WorkZone and you must be able to see the roles loaded there in WZ.

In IAS you must be able to see in the JobLog that users and groups are correctly read from S/4 and written to WZ. If not, you might need to adjust the transformations in the IAS to get rid of errors.

Based on the diagram I do assume the Joule is using one of BTP Destination to connect WZ...

Several months ago when I spoke with experts from SAP about the Destinations used by Joule  I was told by them that the name of the BTP Destination is hard-coded in Joule. 

While writing this post I did check the PDF guide again. I found there info about Joule Admin Center. It seems to be a new interface for customization of the Joule.  See chapter 13 Joule Admin Center in the PDF.

However, I'm not able to access the Admin interface even I have the needed Role assigned, so I'm not able to provide more info about it.

Good luck with debugging üôÇ

entry.title: Re: In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, We can't use the...
entry.content:
Hello @Kimaro 

In S/4HANA Public Cloud edition, the Cumulative processing option is not available for-profit Centre allocations. It is only provided in the Cost Center context. Profit Center cycles run period by period. SAP Help Portal-Divisional Accounting

For the balance sheet (BS) accounts: Use Profit Center allocations monthly, SAP Help Portal-Universal Allocation Run - Profit Centers

SAP Useful References

The documentation shows the execution mechanics you will actually use. Test runs vs live runs, reversals, and recurring schedules monthly runs, are all handled in the Universal Allocation Run and Profit Centers app. If you need ‚Äúcumulative‚Äù behavior, you implement it via a simple YTD true-up after the monthly run. SAP Help Portal-Universal Allocation Run - Profit Centers

SAP Help documents the official method for allocating between Profit Centres in Public Cloud. In S/4HANA Cloud, you define the cycle in Manage Allocations and run it with Universal Allocation Run ‚Äì Profit Centres. That‚Äôs how SAP recommends posting Profit Centre allocations now. SAP Help Portal-Universal Allocation (Profit Center Context)

It outlines the main constraints you need to consider. Profit Center allocations can only post to G/L account types X (Balance Sheet) and N (Non-operating), not to primary or secondary cost elements, ensuring compliance with your requirement to "allocate BS accounts by PC." The documentation also covers "Cumulative‚Äù processing for Cost Centers.  3114399 - Allocating Amounts Between Profit Centers in Universal Allocation

The allowance for account types in PC allocations is restricted to X and N. SAP Support Portal-3515104 - Profit Center Allocation Cycle is not compatible with postings via Primary/Secondary Cost Elements

Use Manage Profit Centers to create or edit PCs, set valid-from and to dates, assign company codes, hierarchy, and segments. Accurate setup is crucial for your Universal Allocation cycles; if a PC is not valid or properly assigned, the process will either skip it or generate an error. SAP Help Portal-Manage Profit Centers

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Can I modify the behaviour of the fields in CJ20N?
entry.content:
As you can see in the transaction SMOD, the screen 600 of program SAPLXCN1 corresponds to the enhancement CNEX0006 to initialize custom fields in the table PROJ. The screen 600 doesn't exist by default, it's up to the customer to create and define it as desired, set read-only fields, and so on.

The screen 700 of program SAPLXCN1 corresponds to the enhancement CNEX0007 to initialize custom fields in the table PRPS. The screen 700 doesn't exist by default, it's up to the customer to create and define it as desired, set read-only fields, and so on.

So, yes, it's possible.

In the flow logic of the screen, call a module in PROCESS BEFORE OUTPUT, and in the module use LOOP AT SCREEN, MODIFY SCREEN. See the ABAP documentation and the forum for more information.

entry.title: Accept Zero as a valid value in a currency field

we have a numeric / currency type field on the database. In this case, the initial status is 0. Now we have the problem that the thousands separators are no longer displayed, which makes readability more difficult for large numbers.

Is there a solution for this problem?
- Database field numerical
- A zero value should be accepted from the user interface as a valid value in a required field check

entry.title: Re: Trigger Equipment Replication (Event Mesh) from S/4HA...
entry.content:
Good day @krri 

Thank you for your question.

Have you had a look at Equipment & Side-by-Side Extensibility with SAP Build Apps -E2E Service covering Customer Service, Field Service?

The summary is, the event-based integration you are trying to carry out only handles changes to existing details (e.g., create, change or delete). There is no built-in initial load through DRF and you cannot replicate models.

  • SAP recommends you use the equipment API to extract all equipment data and push it into your service cloud V2 through CPI or API
  • Alternatively, you can trigger change of events by performing a mass change on a field with no impact. Only do this for small data sets.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Is it Mandatory to have Cloud foundry runtime with Bu...
entry.content:
Having a CF runtime is not mandatory for using BAS, I assume you are going to deploy the FIORI apps back to your S/4 system based.

If not deploying back to S/4 then you will need to have CF runtime for hosting and running your apps. The size will depend on the subaccount strategy and the number of apps that you would deploy in each subaccount and also the load on the application.

I would suggest to go with default size and then scale it as you go.

entry.title: Entity returns duplicate value when used with filters, $top and $skip
entry.content:
We have a CAP Java backend (CAP Java SDK version 4.0.0) with Fiori elements frontend. We use the tree table component in our first list report page of our application. ‚ÄÉ

Tree table in our application : 

So when loading the tree table frontend component, we do the following backend call : 

NameOfOurEntity$apply=orderby(numberOfMetrics%20desc)/com.sap.vocabularies.Hierarchy.v1.TopLevels(HierarchyNodes=$root/NameOfOurEntity,HierarchyQualifier='SystemHierarchy',NodeProperty='id')&$select=DistanceFromRoot,DrillState,LimitedDescendantCount,dataCollectionStatus,dataCollectionStatusLabel,id,name,numberOfMetrics,parentID&$count=true&$skip=0&$top=225

When we apply a filter the following call happens to our backend : 

NameOfOurEntity?$apply=ancestors($root/NameOfOurEntity,SystemHierarchy,id,filter(dataCollectionStatusLabel%20eq%20'NOT_CONFIGURED'),keep%20start)/orderby(numberOfMetrics%20desc)/com.sap.vocabularies.Hierarchy.v1.TopLevels(HierarchyNodes=$root/NameOfOurEntity,HierarchyQualifier='SystemHierarchy',NodeProperty='id')&$select=DistanceFromRoot,DrillState,LimitedDescendantCount,dataCollectionStatus,dataCollectionStatusLabel,id,name,numberOfMetrics,parentID&$count=true&$skip=0&$top=225

Our Backend Entity looks like this : 

 

entity TreeEntityTable as select distinct key id, name, parentID, numberOfMetrics, dataCollectionStatus,
  dataCollectionStatusLabel, serviceType
  from (
    select id, name, parentID, numberOfMetrics, dataCollectionStatus, dataCollectionStatusLabel, serviceType
    from SystemTypes union
    select id, name, parentID, numberOfMetrics, dataCollectionStatus, dataCollectionStatusLabel, serviceType
    from Systems union
    select id, name, parentID, numberOfMetrics, dataCollectionStatus, dataCollectionStatusLabel, serviceType
    from Clients union
    select id, name, parentID, numberOfMetrics, dataCollectionStatus, dataCollectionStatusLabel, serviceType
    from LanscapeObjects
  );
@Capabilities.FilterRestrictions.NonFilterableProperties: [
  'LimitedDescendantCount',
  'DistanceFromRoot',
  'DrillState',
  'LimitedRank',
  'dataCollectionStatus',
  'id',
  'numberOfMetrics',
  'parentID',
  'serviceType'
]
@Capabilities.SortRestrictions.NonSortableProperties: [
  'LimitedDescendantCount',
  'DistanceFromRoot',
  'DrillState',
  'LimitedRank',
  'dataCollectionStatus',
  'id',
  'parentID',
  'serviceType'
]
@cds.search: {
  id,
  name,
  dataCollectionStatusLabel,
  numberOfMetrics,
  serviceType
}
@readonly
entity TreeEntity as projection on TreeEntityTable {
  @title:'{i18n>ID}'
  key id,
  @title:'{i18n>SYSTEM_NAME}'
  name,
  @titl:'{i18n>NUMBER_OF_METRICS}'
  numberOfMetrics,
  @title:'{i18n>DATA_COLLECTION_STATUS}'
  dataCollectionStatus,
  @title:'{i18n>DATA_COLLECTION_STATUS_LABEL}'
  dataCollectionStatusLabel,
  parentID,
  serviceType,
  parent : Association to TreeEntity on parent.id = $self.parentID,
  children : Composition of many TreeEntity on children.parentID = $self.id,
  statusLabelRelation : Association to one TreeEntityTableLabels on statusLabelRelation.dataCollectionStatusLabel = $self.dataCollectionStatusLabel,
  virtual null as LimitedDescendantCount : Integer64,
  virtual null as DistanceFromRoot : Integer64,
  virtual null as DrillState : String,
  virtual null as LimitedRank : Integer64
};

We never expect our backend to return duplicate entries to our frontend but we have see that in few cases when a filter is applied which contains data with more than 1500 entries and when multiple calls to backend with different $top and $skip is fired our backend tends to return duplicate values.

Please do let us know if you have faced the same issue or if you have already come across a fix for it.

entry.title: How to Integrate SAP Commerce with Large Language Models (LLMs) for Intelligent Product Discovery
entry.content:
In the era of AI-driven commerce, product discovery is evolving beyond keyword search and static recommendations. Modern shoppers expect context-aware, conversational, and intent-driven interactions  Show me "budget-friendly noise-canceling headphones for travel"  should instantly return relevant products, not just keyword matches.

Traditional SAP Commerce search engines like Solr or SAP Commerce Search Services work well for structured queries. But they struggle when customers use natural language, fuzzy intents, or multi-attribute requests.

This is where Large Language Models (LLMs) like GPT-4, Claude, or Vertex AI Gemini come in ‚Äî enabling natural understanding of user intent, semantic matching with product data, and even contextual re-ranking.

In this blog, we‚Äôll build an LLM-powered Product Discovery layer on top of SAP Commerce. You‚Äôll learn:

  • How to extract and embed product catalog data.

  • How to build a semantic vector store for products.

  • How to integrate LLM-based intent understanding.

  • How to return ranked, relevant results to the SAP storefront.

Architecture Overview

 

Step 1: Exporting Product Data from SAP Commerce

We first expose a REST API from SAP Commerce that returns key product data for indexing:

// File: ProductExportController.java
package com.aiintegration.controllers;

import de.hybris.platform.commercefacades.product.ProductFacade;
import de.hybris.platform.commercefacades.product.data.ProductData;
import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.*;

import java.util.List;

@RestController
@RequestMapping("/v1/ai/products")
public class ProductExportController {

    private final ProductFacade productFacade;

    public ProductExportController(ProductFacade productFacade) {
        this.productFacade = productFacade;
    }

    @GetMapping
    public List<ProductData> exportProducts() {
        // Export only relevant fields for AI discovery
        return productFacade.getAllProducts().stream()
                .map(p -> {
                    ProductData data = new ProductData();
                    data.setCode(p.getCode());
                    data.setName(p.getName());
                    data.setDescription(p.getDescription());
                    data.setCategory(p.getCategory());
                    data.setPrice(p.getPrice());
                    return data;
                })
                .toList();
    }
}

Step 2: Building the AI Discovery Service (LLM + Vector DB)

Let‚Äôs create a simple AI service that uses OpenAI Embeddings + Qdrant (or Pinecone) for semantic search.

I am using Go Lang here as Go is very powerful , easy to develop & consume less memory. Idea is to externalise the service deploy as side by side in any hyper-scaler environment

Example in Go (using Gin)

package main

import (
    "context"
    "encoding/json"
    "net/http"
    "github.com/gin-gonic/gin"
    openai "github.com/sashabaranov/go-openai"
)

type Product struct {
    Code        string  `json:"code"`
    Name        string  `json:"name"`
    Description string  `json:"description"`
    Category    string  `json:"category"`
    Price       float64 `json:"price"`
}

var client = openai.NewClient("YOUR_OPENAI_API_KEY")
var vectorStore = map[string][]float32{} // Use Qdrant/Pinecone in prod
var productData = []Product{}

func generateEmbeddings(text string) []float32 {
    resp, _ := client.CreateEmbeddings(context.Background(), openai.EmbeddingRequest{
        Input: []string{text},
        Model: openai.AdaEmbeddingV2,
    })
    return resp.Data[0].Embedding
}

func indexProducts(c *gin.Context) {
    json.NewDecoder(c.Request.Body).Decode(&productData)
    for _, p := range productData {
        combined := p.Name + " " + p.Description + " " + p.Category
        vectorStore[p.Code] = generateEmbeddings(combined)
    }
    c.JSON(http.StatusOK, gin.H{"message": "Products indexed"})
}

func searchProducts(c *gin.Context) {
    query := c.Query("q")
    queryVector := generateEmbeddings(query)
    // Compute cosine similarity and rank (simplified)
    results := rankBySimilarity(queryVector)
    c.JSON(http.StatusOK, results)
}

func main() {
    r := gin.Default()
    r.POST("/index", indexProducts)
    r.GET("/search", searchProducts)
    r.Run(":8081")
}

This service indexes SAP Commerce products as embeddings and returns semantic matches for user queries. 

This service can be deployed  in any cloud service provider 

Step 3: Integrating AI Discovery with SAP Storefront

If you‚Äôre using SAP Composable Storefront (Spartacus), you can integrate this AI service easily:

// ai-search.service.ts
@Injectable({ providedIn: 'root' })
export class AiSearchService {
  constructor(private http: HttpClient) {}

  search(query: string): Observable<Product[]> {
    const api = 'https://ai-service.letstravail.com/search?q=' + encodeURIComponent(query);
    return this.http.get<Product[]>(api);
  }
}

And in your Search Results component:

@Component({
  selector: 'cx-ai-search',
  template: `
    <div class="search-container">
      <input [(ngModel)]="query" placeholder="Ask me what you need..." />
      <button (click)="onSearch()">Search</button>

      <div *ngFor="let p of products" class="product-card">
        <h3>{{ p.name }}</h3>
        <p>{{ p.description }}</p>
        <span>{{ p.price | currency }}</span>
      </div>
    </div>
  `
})
export class AiSearchComponent {
  query = '';
  products: Product[] = [];

  constructor(private aiSearch: AiSearchService) {}

  onSearch() {
    this.aiSearch.search(this.query).subscribe(res => this.products = res);
  }
}

Step 4: Intent Understanding with LLMs

For more advanced queries (‚ÄúShow me eco-friendly running shoes under $100‚Äù), we can use GPT-4 or Gemini to extract structured filters from the text:

Example: Query Intent Parsing with GPT

func parseIntent(query string) map[string]interface{} {
    prompt := fmt.Sprintf(`Extract search filters from this query:
    "%s"
    Respond in JSON with keys: category, attributes, priceRange, sentiment`, query)

    resp, _ := client.CreateChatCompletion(context.Background(), openai.ChatCompletionRequest{
        Model: "gpt-4-turbo",
        Messages: []openai.ChatCompletionMessage{
            {Role: "user", Content: prompt},
        },
    })

    var filters map[string]interface{}
    json.Unmarshal([]byte(resp.Choices[0].Message.Content), &filters)
    return filters
}

Example Input:

‚ÄúShow me eco-friendly running shoes under $100‚Äù

LLM OUTPUT

{
  "category": "running shoes",
  "attributes": ["eco-friendly", "sustainable"],
  "priceRange": "<100"
}

These structured filters can refine your SAP Commerce FlexibleSearch or Solr queries for more precise results.

Step 5: Combining Semantic Search + SAP Search

You can now combine  traditional keyword search and LLM-based semantic ranking.

Feature Traditional         Solr Search                     LLM Semantic Search

Query TypeKeyword-basedIntent-based
Fuzzy MatchingLimitedHigh
Multi-attributeComplexNatural
Contextual RankingNoYes
LatencyLowModerate
AccuracyDepends on synonymsLearns semantics

Hybrid Search result example 

// Combine Solr + AI Ranking
List<ProductData> solrResults = solrSearchService.search(query);
List<ProductData> aiResults = aiService.semanticSearch(query);

// Merge based on confidence score
List<ProductData> finalList = mergeResults(solrResults, aiResults);

 Future Extensions

  • Integrate with SAP Joule for enterprise AI context.

  • Use LLM RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) for chatbot-style search.

  • Combine with SAP Commerce Recommendation Services.

  • Deploy the AI service in SAP BTP Kyma (Kubernetes) for scale.

Conclusion

Integrating LLMs with SAP Commerce transforms your storefront into a truly intelligent shopping experience ‚Äî one that understands your customers‚Äô intent, not just their keywords.

By building a semantic layer using embeddings and an LLM-based query parser, you enable human-like product discovery that feels conversational, context-aware, and personalized.

Whether you use OpenAI, Gemini, or SAP Joule, the pattern remains:
Extract ‚Üí Embed ‚Üí Search ‚Üí Rank ‚Üí Learn.

entry.title: How to speed up UI development process using UI5 web components
entry.content:
In the past few weeks I was asked to build a React application to be deployed on BTP. The application needs to be integrated with authentication and destinations to connect to a backend OData API.

I started with the templates available in Build Code to create an application skeleton with these capabilities, and it worked fine. The app communicated via a destination to an OData service deployed in my BTP subaccount; it required authentication. So, at first glance, my job was done.

Then I decided to change the app layout and began modifying the generated components. At that point I realized testing the changes was not straightforward. Running the app locally was possible, but to get the latest changes I had to rebuild the app completely, and that procedure takes time (almost 1 minute).

I wanted a leaner workflow to make changes and test them locally without a full rebuild every time.

Since I‚Äôm not an expert in React development, I asked a colleague, @rpagni, for help. He has solid experience with the framework and said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve faced this problem before ‚Äî let me show you how I solved it.‚Äù His idea was great: use a modern React build tool for faster builds and use the app router to handle both dev and prod versions. That way the app router can easily integrate authentication and backend communication via destinations.

Looking for examples I found this tutorial: https://developers.sap.com/mission.react-spa.html. It uses React and Vite, but unfortunately it doesn‚Äôt connect to a backend service and isn‚Äôt integrated with a multitarget application (MTA).

So, together with @rpagni we decided to document the solution step by step to share our experience. We described every aspect of what we did and explained the choices we made.

 

Steps to create a React application deployable in BTP and using UAA and Destination services

Create Basic Multitarget Application

Open the template wizard and start creating a Multitarget Application project. Assing to the project your preferred name.

Create an Approuter module

In the MTA project create an app router module. To do that:

  1. right click on the mta.yaml file and select Create MTA module from Template.
  2. select Approuter Configuration module
  3. configure the following screen with these values:
    • Application Runtime: Standalone Approuter
    • Add Authentication: Yes
    • Plan to add UI: Yes
  4. if you want to change the app router module name, change the name to the created folder and change, in the mta.yaml file, any reference to the previous folder name with the new name assigned

Change xs-security.json to allow the local app-router to manage authentication

When you run the application, either in dev mode or in production mode, it could happen to get the error:

OpenID provider cannot process the request because the redirect_uri does not match the configuration. Please contact your system administrator.

This is an error related to the authentication process. The app router redirects the user session to the authetication service and this raises an error. The reason is about the fact that the expected redirect URI, provided as parameter to the authentication service, it is not part of the allowed redirect URIs. To solve this issue, add to the xs-security.json the following allowed URIs patterns. Add the following object property to the configuration (adapt the patterns to your specific subaccount URLs):

,
  "oauth2-configuration": {
      "redirect-uris": [
          "https://*.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/login/callback",
          "https://*.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/login/callback",
          "https://*.applicationstudio.cloud.sap/login/callback"
      ]
  }

Crate a React Vite project

Create a React project with your preferred build tool, in this case we use Vite template see an example here. This template will create a React project using the SAPUI5 web components

Open terminal, navigate to the project root folder and run the commands (events-app is the folder name):

npx degit UI5/webcomponents-react/templates/vite-ts#main events-app

cd events-app

npm i

Properly setup Vite project

In the Vite project perform these activities:

  1. change the vite.config.ts with this content:
    import { defineConfig } from "vite"; import react from "@vitejs/plugin-react"; import path from "path";
export default defineConfig({ 
      plugins: [react()], 
      server: { 
        hmr: { port: 5174, }, 
      }, 
      build: { 
        outDir: "../test-react-approuter/dist", 
        emptyOutDir: true, 
      }, 
      resolve: { 
        alias: { 
         "@": path.resolve(__dirname, "./src"), 
        }, 
      }, 
    });

purpose of this code is:

  • setup a fixed port (5174) for the preview service
  • define the build directory: once the project is built, this is the place where to store the built files. This config defines to store the /dist folder within the app router folder, this is needed later on when the routes are defined in the xs-app.json

  • set an alias on the subfolders contained within the react project source folder

  • import the path library typing the command

    npm i path -s

  • in the tsconfig.json add, in the compilerOptions ojects, the 2 properties

     "baseUrl": ".",
 "paths": {
     "@/*": ["./src/*"]
 }

Edit mta.yaml file

The purpose of this edting is to add a resource declaration to define a destination service instance, once the mta will be deployed and add a reference to this service to the app router module. The need of this setting is to allow the app router to access the destination service and connect, via a destination reported withint the xs-app.json, to the backend service needed to consume the corresponding APIs (in my case the APIs managing events data). For doing that proceed as defined here:

  1. in the resources section (end of the file) add a resource defining a destination service instance. For example:
     - name: dest_events-react-app
 type: org.cloudfoundry.managed-service
 parameters:
     service: destination
     service-name: dest_events-react-app
     service-plan: lite
  2. in the app router module definition, add a reference to such a resource in the requires section:
     requires:
   - name: events-react-app_html_repo_runtime 
       - name: uaa_events-react-app 
       - name: dest_events-react-app
  3. remove the deployer module: having selected the standalone app router as application runtime, the wizard creates.

Build and deploy the project

With this activity the aim is to deploy the mtar file corresponding to this project. The goal is not to have a productive version of the app, but simply to let the deployment process to istantiate the declared xsuaa and destination services. Later you will download the corresponding env data realted to them.

  1. right click on the mta.yaml file and select the build command
  2. once the build is finished, find the generated mtar file, right click on it and select to deploy (be sure to be authenticated to any valid BTP subaccount and space with some available runtime resources assigned).

Once deployed, check in the space applications to find an app named as the app router module.

Setup the app router module to manage both the productive and the development app execution

The goal of this step is to properly structure the app router module in order to let the user both test locally the application without any need of code rebuild and having the application working productively, as well.

Create a dev folder in the module

The purpose of this folder is to define a developer configuration for the app router. The content of this folder is used to serve the application during the development phase and not require any application build process.

  1. create a folder called (for example) dev in the app-approuter folder

  2. open the package.json and change the script start-local with this command:

    node node_modules/@sap/approuter/approuter.js --workingDir dev

    this commanda runs the app router with the configuration defined in the next steps in folder dev

  3. move to folder dev and copy and paste the xs-app.json file, available in the app-approuter folder
  4. create a default-env.json file in the dev folder. This file will be used by the @sap/approuter library to connect to the xsuaa and destination services available in BTP. In this way, during the development phase, the developer can test the authetication/authorization (for example checking whether the assigned scopes are working properly) and the destination connectivity as per the productive version of the app. To create the file:
    1. open BTP cockpit and navigate to the space applications page. Here identify the deployed app router application and click on it
    2. in the menu on the left side click on the item Environment Variables
    3. copy the whole content in the area called System Provided
    4. paste the content into the file default-env.json then perform these actions:
      • delete the whole json object containing the property VCAP_APPLICATION, just keep the one containing the VCAP_SERVICES property
      • in the object VCAP_SERVICES delete the following properties: destination and html5-apps-repo
      • add a property named destinations at the same level of the property VCAP_SERVICES. Its value must be:
          "destinations":[
      {
          "name":"EventsBooking-app-srv2",
          "url":"https://EventsBooking-app-srv2.dest",
          "proxyHost":"http://127.0.0.1",
          "proxyPort":"8887"
      },{
          "name": "vite-dev-server",
          "url": "http://localhost:5174"
      }
  ]
        In this section you have to add all the destionations the react app will use to get data out of external APIs. In the example above there are declared 2 destinations:
        • EventsBooking-app-srv2: it is the BTP destination targeting the Events Management APIs, will be used by the app to get/store events data. Pay attention to the url parameter, it declares to use the URL defined at BTP destination level, so you don't need to hard code it. Leave the proxy parameters as in the example. These provide to BAS the way to communicate with BTP
        • vite-dev-server: it is the destination targeting the URL of the local running react app. The port reported in the URL is the one defined in the file vite.config.ts. This destination let the local app router to forward the local react app calls to the running vite preview execution

  5. Adjust the xs-app.json file in the dev folder: this activity has the aim to define all the local app router configurations, like for example the welcome page, the routes etc. In this case the configuration is as follow:

     {
     "welcomeFile": "index.html",
     "authenticationMethod": "route",
     "routes": [
         {
             "authenticationType": "xsuaa",
             "csrfProtection": false,
             "source": "^/EventsBooking-app-srv2/(.*)$",
             "destination": "EventsBooking-app-srv2",
             "target": "$1"
         },
         {
             "source": "^/user-api(.*)",
             "target": "$1",
             "service": "sap-approuter-userapi"
         },
         {
             "source": "^(.*)$",
             "target": "/$1",
             "destination": "vite-dev-server",
             "authenticationType": "none"
         }
     ],
     "compression": {
         "enabled": false
     }
 }

    the most important part is the routes array. In this array you have to define all the routes the local app router must use. Rember that the routes are processed from the top (array element 0) to the bottom (array element N). The first that matches is the one executed. In this case the meaning of the routes are:

    1. forward to the destinantion EventsBooking-app-srv2 all the app calls to URL path starting with the prefix /EventsBooking-app-srv2. All these calls are defined in the app as the once to interact with the events managment OData service
    2. forward all the calls with URL path starting with /user-api to the standard sap-approuter-userapi user api service. This service provides data about current logged in user, like user name and authorization scopes assigned see here for more info
    3. this route forwards all the local api calls to the vite preview service running. Each and every time the react app needs to donwload an asset, a css, js, etc files these requests are routed to the preview service. this is the route that makes the magic happens, that allows the developer to test the changes without fully rebuilding the application.

Adjust the xs-app.json for the productive usage

In the previous paragraph you setup the environment for the development phase, but once the app will be built and deployed this doesn't served the productive code. For this reason it is needed to setup the xs-app.json in the app router folder module.

  1. open the xs-app.json file contained in the root folder of the app router module.
  2. setup its content as expected for the prodcutive usage. In this example its content is:
    {
 "authenticationMethod": "route",
 "welcomeFile": "index.html",
 "routes": [
     {
         "authenticationType": "xsuaa",
         "csrfProtection": false,
         "source": "^/EventsBooking-app-srv2/(.*)$",
         "destination": "EventsBooking-app-srv2",
         "target": "$1"
     },
     {
         "source": "^/user-api(.*)",
         "target": "$1",
         "service": "sap-approuter-userapi"
     },
     {
         "source": "^(.*)$",
         "target": "$1",
         "localDir": "dist",
         "cacheControl": "no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate"
     }
 ],
 "compression": {
     "enabled": false
 }
}
    the difference with the dev version of the same file is in the third route. This route says to the app router to route all the react app calls, which not have the prefixes defined by the first two ones, to the local folder called dist. This is the folder, set in the vite.config.ts, where the full build process will store the output of the build procedure. In other words, it is the folder containing the productive version of the react app code.

Once the app will be deployed and running, every local app call for downloading assets, files (like css, js, etc) will be forwarded to the content of that folder.

Optimize the mta building procedure

To optimize the mta building procedure proceed as described below:

  1. create a script in the package.json contained in the app router folder with this name and command:

    "build": "cd ../events-app && npm run build"

    this command allows to trigger che building of the react app as soon as the app router module build is triggered (see next paragraphs). The script move the context to the react app folder and run the build script contained there

  2. change the mta.yaml file as following:

in the app router module append the following configuration:

 build-parameters:
     ignore:
     - node_modules
     builder: custom
     commands:
     - npm run build

this configuration avoid to include, in the final mtar file, any node_modules folder and, before build the module, runs the script build created beforehand to trigger the vite build command for the react app

Test the app in dev mode

To test the app in dev mode proceed as following:

  1. open a terminal window
  2. move to the react app folder

  3. run the command

    npm run dev

    this command starts the application in dev mode on port 5174, as per app configuration. No need to rebuild the app the see the changes

  4. open a new terminal window and move in the approuter folder
  5. run the script start-local, this run the app router using the config stored in the dev folder.
  6. run a preview of the app on the port 5000
  7. make any change in the code, refresh the app preview and check whether the change is replicated properly

Test the app in productive mode

To test the app in productive mode, simply bluid the mta.yaml file and deploy the generated mtar.

ATTENTION: if you deploy on the same space where you perfomed the first deployment, you need to get again the environment variables of the app, copy just the property xsuaa and used it to replace the same property in the defaul-env.json file. Remind to stop and restart the local running app router to make the change available

If you don't want to overwrite the value of the property xsuaa, deploy the app in a different space of a different account.

entry.title: Re: Unable to Post Direct Activity Allocation to Event-Ba...
Re: Intelligent Natural-Language Interaction in ABAP UIs ‚Äî Introducing the FPM GenAI Service
entry.content:
Dear Cocquerel,

Thanks for your comment.

You‚Äôre right that RAP and SAPUI5/Fiori are the strategic technologies for new ABAP developments. However, FPM for Web Dynpro ABAP remains the standard UI framework for a large installed base of business applications, especially in the S/4HANA on-premise and private cloud editions. These applications continue to evolve and comply with current SAP product standards ‚Äî so they are maintained, not legacy!

The FPM GenAI Service brings generative AI interaction into this environment, enabling natural-language operation and automation without requiring a technology migration. For RAP/SAPUI5, there are indeed multiple AI integration paths ‚Äî most prominently through SAP Joule and BTP AI services. Our goal is to connect the FPM GenAI Service with Joule as well, so that customers benefit from a consistent AI experience across both FPM and RAP/Fiori applications.

Best regards,

Simon

entry.title: Conversion of SHIFT-JIS Encoding to UTF-8 Encoding for CSV File
entry.content:
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report ZCSV_CONVERSION3
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*&
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
REPORT ysap_shiftjis_to_utf8_csv.

PARAMETERS:
  p_infile TYPE ibipparms-path, "" Pick the file from system
  p_out    TYPE string. ""Assign a path and file name for output file path

DATA:
  lt_raw_data   TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF x255,
  lv_xstring    TYPE xstring,
  lv_string     TYPE string,
  lv_utf8_xstr  TYPE xstring,
  lt_output_raw TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF x255,
  lv_filelen    TYPE i,
  lv_file       TYPE string.

CLASS cl_abap_conv_in_ce DEFINITION LOAD.
CLASS cl_abap_conv_out_ce DEFINITION LOAD.

AT SELECTION-SCREEN ON VALUE-REQUEST FOR p_infile.
  CALL FUNCTION 'F4_FILENAME'
    EXPORTING
      program_name  = syst-cprog
      dynpro_number = syst-dynnr
    IMPORTING
      file_name     = p_infile.

START-OF-SELECTION.
  " Step 1: Upload Shift-JIS file as binary
  lv_file =  p_infile.
  CALL METHOD cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_upload
    EXPORTING
      filename   = lv_file
      filetype   = 'BIN'
    IMPORTING
      filelength = lv_filelen
    CHANGING
      data_tab   = lt_raw_data.
  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    MESSAGE 'File upload failed' TYPE 'E'.
  ENDIF.

  " Step 2: Convert RAW table to XSTRING
  CALL FUNCTION 'SCMS_BINARY_TO_XSTRING'
    EXPORTING
      input_length = lv_filelen
    IMPORTING
      buffer       = lv_xstring
    TABLES
      binary_tab   = lt_raw_data
    EXCEPTIONS
      failed       = 1
      OTHERS       = 2.

  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    MESSAGE 'Conversion of RAW to XSTRING failed' TYPE 'E'.
  ENDIF.

  " Step 3: Decode Shift-JIS XSTRING to ABAP string
  DATA(lo_in) = cl_abap_conv_in_ce=>create( encoding = '8300' ).
  lo_in->convert(
    EXPORTING
      input = lv_xstring
    IMPORTING
      data  = lv_string ).

  " Step 4: Encode ABAP string to UTF-8 XSTRING
  DATA(lo_out) = cl_abap_conv_out_ce=>create( encoding = '4103' ).
  lo_out->convert(
    EXPORTING
      data   = lv_string
    IMPORTING
      buffer = lv_utf8_xstr ).

  " Step 5: Convert UTF-8 XSTRING back to RAW table
  CLEAR lt_output_raw.
  CALL FUNCTION 'SCMS_XSTRING_TO_BINARY'
    EXPORTING
      buffer     = lv_utf8_xstr
    TABLES
      binary_tab = lt_output_raw
    EXCEPTIONS
      failed     = 1
      OTHERS     = 2.
  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    MESSAGE 'XSTRING to binary conversion failed' TYPE 'E'.
  ENDIF.

  " Step 6: Download as UTF-8 file
  CALL METHOD cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_download
    EXPORTING
      filename                = p_out
      filetype                = 'BIN'
    CHANGING
      data_tab                = lt_output_raw
    EXCEPTIONS
      file_write_error        = 1
      no_batch                = 2
      gui_refuse_filetransfer = 3
      invalid_type            = 4
      unknown_error           = 5
      OTHERS                  = 6.
  IF sy-subrc = 0.
    MESSAGE 'File converted successfully to UTF-8' TYPE 'S'.
  ELSE.
    MESSAGE 'Download failed' TYPE 'E'.
  ENDIF.

entry.title: Re: Foreign currency decimal places setting
entry.content: Test results for a payment transaction 1). SAP Business One 10.0 (10.00.180) FP 2111 (64-bit) A USD 10.11 A/R invoice was partially paid with USD 10. Expected result: The 'Payment on Account' field should display -0.11. Actual result: The system rounds the value and leaves the field blank, while another field below shows -0.11. 2). SAP Business One 10.0 (10.00.200) FP 2208 (64-bit) A USD 16,094.35 A/R invoice was partially paid with USD 16,094. The 'Payment on Account' field correctly displays -0.35. 3). SAP Business One 10.0 version for SAP HANA (10.00.230) SP 2311 (64-bit) The test result is the same as in case (2). Additionally, I have confirmed that SAP systems running the same FP2111 version and even older versions (such as 9.2 PL12) produce the same result as in case (1), where the decimal places are not displayed. I suspect this issue might be related to version differences.

entry.title: Re: "Text Through Text Associations" in RAP triggers exce...
entry.content:
I know this is an old question, but I've run into it before, so this is more of a 'note to self' for next time üòÄ

The solution is given here:

Getting Language-Dependent Text in Projection Views | SAP Help Portal

You cannot use the ObjectModel.text.association annotation, but you need to use @ObjectModel.text.element: [<text_element>] and then add the text field from an association and use the 'localized' keyword.

Prerequisites

  • The text provider view has a key element indicating the language of the text.
  • The projected CDS view has an association to the text provider view, but does not use the annotation ObjectModel.text.association.

Procedure

  1. Include the text element from the text provider view into the projection view.
  2. Annotate the element in the projection view, for which you want to provide the text with @ObjectModel.text.element: [<text_element>] and reference the text element.
  3. To get language-dependent texts use the keyword localized on the text element.
